timeline.message: NF: kill Task_Type_Count_Models when ModelBrowser close

timeline.bodyText: When would this be called on restore?
timeline.author: david-allison-1

timeline.message: NF: kill Task_Type_Count_Models when ModelBrowser close

timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText:
Quite hard to say, because even if I can still open and close the list of note type, I can't be sure that the request was actually cancelled.
I've not check cat to ensure that cancellation was done.
According to https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/AsyncTask#cancel(boolean)
onPostExecute is not run when the task is cancelled. I guess that I could as well have returned null
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

replies.bodyText: Okay - let's add a comment that the choice is explicit, then we're good to go
replies.author: david-allison-1

timeline.message: NF: kill Task_Type_Count_Models when ModelBrowser close

timeline.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: Comment added. Returning null since we do not actually care about the value
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.message: NF: kill Task_Type_Count_Models when ModelBrowser close

timeline.bodyText: onPostExecute also crashes on null, could we handle this case if we're going to imply it's fine.
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText:
I do not understand your request. Do you want onPostExecute to check for non-null value ?
I guess we could, and behave the same way as when it gets a False value, i.e. throw an exception.
I fail to see the point, since this method return null only if task is cancelled, and in this case onPostExecute is not executed. So there should be no way for onPostExecute to obtain the null
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

replies.bodyText:
perhaps even stronger is a change to BaseAsyncTask::onPostExecute that strongly verifies BaseAsyncTask::isCancelled == false, and otherwise does a Timber.w / sendExceptionReport and returns
Basically we have a fear that there will be unpredictable onPostExecute behavior and the risk is the system does not follow it's guidance that onPostExecute won't happen if cancelled, so let's manage the risk directly instead of in client code?
I verified BaseAyncTask::onPostExecute is called first in the delegate objects.
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: I guess to be fully safe until that proposed change to BaseAsyncTask::onPostExecute proves to our satisfaction we are safe, then the client code would also need to null check and say via Timber effectively "this is never supposed to happen, we were called after a cancel"
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: This is just from a maintenance point of view - people are likely to copy/paste and return null in the future on an edge case, as it looks safe, and we should protect against this.
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText:
To restate. I'm happy that onPostExecute won't run.
I'm concerned that we've introduced the logic: "It's OK to return null, as long as we're in an isCanceled() block", as that breaks the principle of least astonishment
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Then stated most explicitly: to approve you require either null handling, or the return false again? And to be least-surprising returning false might be most consistent?
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText:
I added back "False" then. I have no strong opinion here. My weak opinion is that the least astonishing thing would be to return "null" in both cases, since there is nothing "false" here.
Actually, I believe there is little reason to catch the potential exception only to throw a new one (with less details) in onPostExecute, so I believe the try/catch should be removed
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

replies.bodyText: Returning null and handling it seems like the best option, but yes, would be happy with both options
replies.author: david-allison-1
